texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I enjoy taking Fedora with me to various clouds and ensuring that it works well on all of them. I've written posts on taking  Fedora to Hetzner cloud and  deploying custom Fedora images  to AWS with image builder.
texts.text: I enjoy taking Fedora with me to various clouds and ensuring that it works well on all of them. I've written posts on taking  Fedora to Hetzner cloud and  deploying custom Fedora images  to AWS with image builder.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Although Oracle Cloud isn't a cloud I use frequently, a question came up earlier this week in the Fedora community about how to take an image there. I love a good challenge, so buckle up and follow along as we launch a Fedora 38 instance on Oracle Cloud .
texts.text: Although Oracle Cloud isn't a cloud I use frequently, a question came up earlier this week in the Fedora community about how to take an image there. I love a good challenge, so buckle up and follow along as we launch a Fedora 38 instance on Oracle Cloud .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: {{< alert >}} Be sure to create an Oracle Cloud account first! The rest of the blog post requires CLI interactions with the Oracle Cloud API. {{< /alert >}}
texts.text: {{< alert >}} Be sure to create an Oracle Cloud account first! The rest of the blog post requires CLI interactions with the Oracle Cloud API. {{< /alert >}}

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's go! 🎒
texts.text: Let's go! 🎒

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Oracle's cloud tools
texts.text: Oracle's cloud tools

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Although you can do the image upload and import via the web interface, I enjoy getting to learn a cloud provider's CLI tools in case I need them later. Oracle offers a CLI called
texts.text: Although you can do the image upload and import via the web interface, I enjoy getting to learn a cloud provider's CLI tools in case I need them later. Oracle offers a CLI called

texts.label: code
texts.orig: oci
texts.text: oci

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: that you can install via
texts.text: that you can install via

texts.label: code
texts.orig: pipx
texts.text: pipx

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ pipx install oci-cli
  installed package oci-cli 3.26.0, installed using Python 3.11.3
  These apps are now globally available
    - create_backup_from_onprem
    - oci
done! ✨ 🌟 ✨

$ oci --version
3.26.0
texts.text:
$ pipx install oci-cli
  installed package oci-cli 3.26.0, installed using Python 3.11.3
  These apps are now globally available
    - create_backup_from_onprem
    - oci
done! ✨ 🌟 ✨

$ oci --version
3.26.0

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The CLI tool has a helpful authentication wizard that configures your credentials on your local machine. Run
texts.text: The CLI tool has a helpful authentication wizard that configures your credentials on your local machine. Run

texts.label: code
texts.orig: oci -i
texts.text: oci -i

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: and follow the prompts.
texts.text: and follow the prompts.

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ oci session authenticate

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A long URL will appear on the console. Open that URL in a browser and finish the login process in your browser. Once you finish, you should see a message like this:
texts.text: A long URL will appear on the console. Open that URL in a browser and finish the login process in your browser. Once you finish, you should see a message like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
Enter the name of the profile you would like to create: DEFAULT
Config written to: /home/major/.oci/config

    Try out your newly created session credentials with the following example command:

    oci iam region list --config-file /home/major/.oci/config --profile DEFAULT --auth security_token
texts.text:
Enter the name of the profile you would like to create: DEFAULT
Config written to: /home/major/.oci/config

    Try out your newly created session credentials with the following example command:

    oci iam region list --config-file /home/major/.oci/config --profile DEFAULT --auth security_token

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Replace  major  with your username and try out your authentication:
texts.text: Replace  major  with your username and try out your authentication:

texts.label: code
paragraph
texts.orig: Success! Let's move on.
texts.text: Success! Let's move on.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Uploading the Fedora image
texts.text: Uploading the Fedora image

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Most cloud providers have a custom image process that involves uploading the image to some object storage and then telling the compute service where the image is located. Oracle Cloud follows the same pattern.
texts.text: Most cloud providers have a custom image process that involves uploading the image to some object storage and then telling the compute service where the image is located. Oracle Cloud follows the same pattern.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: First up, we need our  compartment ID . This is a way to logically separate infrastructure at Oracle Cloud. We will store it as an environment variable called
texts.text: First up, we need our  compartment ID . This is a way to logically separate infrastructure at Oracle Cloud. We will store it as an environment variable called

texts.label: code
texts.orig: COMPARTMENT_ID
texts.text: COMPARTMENT_ID

texts.label: code
texts.orig: $ COMPARTMENT_ID=$(oci iam compartment list --auth security_token | jq -r '.data[]."compartment-id"')
texts.text: $ COMPARTMENT_ID=$(oci iam compartment list --auth security_token | jq -r '.data[]."compartment-id"')

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We need an object storage bucket to hold our image file. Naming things isn't my strong suit, so I'll call my bucket  majors-fedora-upload-bucket :
texts.text: We need an object storage bucket to hold our image file. Naming things isn't my strong suit, so I'll call my bucket  majors-fedora-upload-bucket :

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ oci os bucket create --name majors-fedora-upload-bucket \
    --compartment-id $COMPARTMENT_ID --auth security_token
{
  "data": {
    "approximate-count": null,
    "approximate-size": null,
    "auto-tiering": null,
    ...
texts.text:
$ oci os bucket create --name majors-fedora-upload-bucket \
    --compartment-id $COMPARTMENT_ID --auth security_token
{
  "data": {
    "approximate-count": null,
    "approximate-size": null,
    "auto-tiering": null,
    ...

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: {{< alert >}} Within the data that is returned, look for the  namespace  key. You will need the value from that key when you do the image import step. {{< /alert >}}
texts.text: {{< alert >}} Within the data that is returned, look for the  namespace  key. You will need the value from that key when you do the image import step. {{< /alert >}}

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now we need a Fedora image. The latest  Fedora 38 QCOW image should work fine.
texts.text: Now we need a Fedora image. The latest  Fedora 38 QCOW image should work fine.

texts.label: code
texts.orig: $ wget https://mirrors.kernel.org/fedora/releases/38/Cloud/x86_64/images/Fedora-Cloud-Base-38-1.6.x86_64.qcow2
texts.text: $ wget https://mirrors.kernel.org/fedora/releases/38/Cloud/x86_64/images/Fedora-Cloud-Base-38-1.6.x86_64.qcow2

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: (Oracle Cloud has aarch64 instances and you can use a Fedora aarch64 image for those instead. This example focuses on x86_64.)
texts.text: (Oracle Cloud has aarch64 instances and you can use a Fedora aarch64 image for those instead. This example focuses on x86_64.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Upload the image to our bucket:
texts.text: Upload the image to our bucket:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ oci os object put \
    --bucket-name majors-fedora-upload-bucket \
    --file ~/Downloads/Fedora-Cloud-Base-38-1.6.x86_64.qcow2 \
    --auth security_token
Upload ID: 0f9b7008-b2d5-185f-08c7-8aeae904f136
Split file into 4 parts for upload.
Uploading object  [####################################]  100%          
{
  "etag": "c0f1bd77-46c6-4e65-a2bb-0d0b0dafe586",
  "last-modified": "Fri, 05 May 2023 21:33:41 GMT",
  "opc-multipart-md5": "iK+1qeXizzd1r+5lEZX6cQ==-4"
}
texts.text:
$ oci os object put \
    --bucket-name majors-fedora-upload-bucket \
    --file ~/Downloads/Fedora-Cloud-Base-38-1.6.x86_64.qcow2 \
    --auth security_token
Upload ID: 0f9b7008-b2d5-185f-08c7-8aeae904f136
Split file into 4 parts for upload.
Uploading object  [####################################]  100%          
{
  "etag": "c0f1bd77-46c6-4e65-a2bb-0d0b0dafe586",
  "last-modified": "Fri, 05 May 2023 21:33:41 GMT",
  "opc-multipart-md5": "iK+1qeXizzd1r+5lEZX6cQ==-4"
}

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This may take a while depending on your upload speed.
texts.text: This may take a while depending on your upload speed.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Import the Fedora image
texts.text: Import the Fedora image

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you forgot to save the namespace from your bucket when you created it, just look it up again with the
texts.text: If you forgot to save the namespace from your bucket when you created it, just look it up again with the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: bucket get
texts.text: bucket get

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: command:
texts.text: command:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ oci os bucket get --name majors-fedora-upload-bucket \
    --auth security_token | jq -r '.data.namespace'
axr6swqvwoeb
texts.text:
$ oci os bucket get --name majors-fedora-upload-bucket \
    --auth security_token | jq -r '.data.namespace'
axr6swqvwoeb

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: At this point, we must tell Oracle's compute service to import the image we just uploaded to the object storage. Let's run another command to do the import:
texts.text: At this point, we must tell Oracle's compute service to import the image we just uploaded to the object storage. Let's run another command to do the import:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ oci compute image import from-object --auth security_token \
    --bucket-name majors-fedora-upload-bucket \
    --compartment-id $COMPARTMENT_ID \
    --name "Fedora-Cloud-Base-38-1.6.x86_64.qcow2" \
    --namespace axr6swqvwoeb \
    --display-name Fedora-Cloud-Base-38-1.6 \
    --operating-system Fedora \
    --operating-system-version 38 \
    --source-image-type QCOW2 \
    --launch-mode PARAVIRTUALIZED
{
  "data": {
    "agent-features": null,
    "base-image-id": null,
    "billable-size-in-gbs": null,
texts.text:
$ oci compute image import from-object --auth security_token \
    --bucket-name majors-fedora-upload-bucket \
    --compartment-id $COMPARTMENT_ID \
    --name "Fedora-Cloud-Base-38-1.6.x86_64.qcow2" \
    --namespace axr6swqvwoeb \
    --display-name Fedora-Cloud-Base-38-1.6 \
    --operating-system Fedora \
    --operating-system-version 38 \
    --source-image-type QCOW2 \
    --launch-mode PARAVIRTUALIZED
{
  "data": {
    "agent-features": null,
    "base-image-id": null,
    "billable-size-in-gbs": null,

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Look for the
texts.text: Look for the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: id
texts.text: id

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: in the output that was returned. Use that identifier to check the status of the import.
texts.text: in the output that was returned. Use that identifier to check the status of the import.

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ export IMAGE_ID=ocid1.image.oc1.phx.aaaaaaaayiu26gv67exe7mvpxkq76zwh44otstzktzaf2f6vqe5izqzrciqq
$ oci compute image get --auth security_token \
    --image-id $IMAGE_ID | jq -r '.data."lifecycle-state"'
IMPORTING
texts.text:
$ export IMAGE_ID=ocid1.image.oc1.phx.aaaaaaaayiu26gv67exe7mvpxkq76zwh44otstzktzaf2f6vqe5izqzrciqq
$ oci compute image get --auth security_token \
    --image-id $IMAGE_ID | jq -r '.data."lifecycle-state"'
IMPORTING

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This step takes about ten minutes for most images I tested.
texts.text: This step takes about ten minutes for most images I tested.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Oracle Cloud uses  work requests  for most long running actions in the cloud. You can get their status via the CLI tools, but I found that to be extremely tedious. For a percentage completed and a progress bar, go to the  Custom Images  panel in the web interface, click your image name, click the  Create image  link under  Work requests  and monitor the percentage there. 😉
texts.text: Oracle Cloud uses  work requests  for most long running actions in the cloud. You can get their status via the CLI tools, but I found that to be extremely tedious. For a percentage completed and a progress bar, go to the  Custom Images  panel in the web interface, click your image name, click the  Create image  link under  Work requests  and monitor the percentage there. 😉

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Create an instance
texts.text: Create an instance

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The
texts.text: The

texts.label: code
texts.orig: oci
texts.text: oci

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: CLI tool is good at many things, but it's tedious with many others. Launching a VM instance via the CLI was incredibly frustrating for me, so I usually go to the web interface to get this done.  (You could also use tools like Terraform for this step.)
texts.text: CLI tool is good at many things, but it's tedious with many others. Launching a VM instance via the CLI was incredibly frustrating for me, so I usually go to the web interface to get this done.  (You could also use tools like Terraform for this step.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's run through the steps:
texts.text: Let's run through the steps:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Go to the
texts.text: Go to the

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Click the
texts.text: Click the

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Click
texts.text: Click

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Click the
texts.text: Click the

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Click
texts.text: Click

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Choose your preferred
texts.text: Choose your preferred

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Choose your SSH key
texts.text: Choose your SSH key

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Click
texts.text: Click

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now you should have an instance beginning to launch! 🚀
texts.text: Now you should have an instance beginning to launch! 🚀

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After it's online, you should be able to ssh[^cantconnect] to the instance using the fedora  user:
texts.text: After it's online, you should be able to ssh[^cantconnect] to the instance using the fedora  user:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ ssh fedora@129.146.75.xxx
[fedora@fedora-38-oracle-whee ~]$ cat /etc/fedora-release 
Fedora release 38 (Thirty Eight)
texts.text:
$ ssh fedora@129.146.75.xxx
[fedora@fedora-38-oracle-whee ~]$ cat /etc/fedora-release 
Fedora release 38 (Thirty Eight)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Enjoy running Fedora on Oracle Cloud! 🎉
texts.text: Enjoy running Fedora on Oracle Cloud! 🎉

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: [^cantconnect]: If you aren't able to access the instance, you might be missing an internet gateway or a security group to allow traffic through to your instance. Here are direct links to the console instructions for those items:
texts.text: [^cantconnect]: If you aren't able to access the instance, you might be missing an internet gateway or a security group to allow traffic through to your instance. Here are direct links to the console instructions for those items:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
* [Adding security groups](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Network/Concepts/networksecuritygroups.htm#console)
* [Working with internet gateways](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Network/Tasks/managingIGs.htm#console)
texts.text:
* [Adding security groups](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Network/Concepts/networksecuritygroups.htm#console)
* [Working with internet gateways](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Network/Tasks/managingIGs.htm#console)
